item.description: Join the next stream when we wrap up part 2 of what people always get wrong about Hart’s legal positivism.

item.title: HLA Hart's The Concept of Law: What Everyone Gets Wrong! [Part 1]
item.description: This Thursday we’re taking a look at HLA Hart’s seminal work: The Concept of Law. It was Hart’s most complete formulation of his legal postivism (in part because he updated it over the course of his career). We’ll take a look at the intro to the newest edition, written by legal philosopher Leslie Green, who brilliantly explains the various parts of Hart’s theory that have been misunderstood.

item.title: Hans Kelsen and the Pure Theory of Law
item.description: On our next stream we’ll be covering Hans Kelsen’s Pure Theory of Law. Specifically, We’ll be discussing his views on the Basic Norm (the Grundnorm), which is the rule that forms the underlying basis for the unified nature of a legal system. Reading for this stream is: Hans Kelsen, A Pure Theory of Law (trans. by Max Knight, University of California Press, 1967) pp. 193-195, 198-201, and 208-14.

item.title: John Stuart Mill on Free Speech
item.description: Overview Discussion Today’s Question To what extent should the government reglate speech? On Liberty, Chapter 2: Of the Liberty of Thought and Discussion John Stuart Mill on Freedom of Speech Famous for his utilitarian ethics Argued that the state should never prohibit an opinion, no matter how false, misleading, or dangerous. One limitation - his argument applies to speech, not to actions.

item.title: John Austin's Command Theory of Law and Legal Positivsm
item.description: Today’s Question What are the validity conditions for a law? Under what conditions do laws exist? Legal Positivism The existence laws depends on social facts and not on the merits of its content. Austin’s Take The existence of law is one thing its merit and demerit another. Whether it be or be not is one inquiry; whether it be or be not comfortable to an assumed standard is a different inquiry.

item.title: The Hart Dworkin Debate (Part 1)
item.description: The Question for Today What is the relationship between law and morality? A (Very) Short History of Legal Positivsm Legal positivism is the thesis that the existence and content of law depends on social facts and not on its merits (Green and Adams, 2019). Austinian Legal Positivism John Austin (1790-1859) argued that laws are the commands of a sovereign backed by threat of sanctions.

item.title: Natural Law Theories
item.description: The Two Main Questions Q: What would a full understanding of the law include? Q: Would a full understanding include some standard of rationality or only include some set of social facts? The Two Main Principles of Law Law is necessarily a socially recognized standard of conduct Law is necessarily a rational standard of conduct. Reasons for Action The motivation for thinking (2) is that we need to explain how the law can provide us with reasons for us to act What is Natural Law Anyway?
